channel.title: How do i release the client? :o
channel.description: my server is finally complete with all portforwarding and coding, but i have one question: what do i need to do to the client before i give it out, i cant just give them the whole client folder, right?

item.title: How do i release the client? :o
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

[quote]because you’re not running the tests at the same time.

Can you provide a link or maybe explain why tests should be at the same time and go into a little more detail? I am curious and would like to learn.[/quote]The system is under different levels of stress at different times. Look at CPU usage over time. It is not a pattern, nor is it constant. You also have the GC, which may run at any time. Also, try running the same benchmark over and over; sometimes you can get swings bigger than 20% with the exact same benchmark.

For more detail: Imagine you have your AV set to scan at a certain time. You run one benchmark, then right before you start the next it starts scanning. Do you think the results would be truly representative? Sure, that doesn’t typically happen, but how many services, processes, etc. do you have running that all have fluctuation in their resource usage? The same goes with the GC itself, you can run your benchmark for the first thing, with no GCs, then during the next benchmark it might GC, dealing a huge blow to the second thing being tested. I’m not even going to get into the issues that JIT compilation can cause with this…

Anyway, people have written papers on these things, so if you want more info, just do a search for papers on Java microbenchmarking.

Read full topic

[quote author=.S. v2 link=topic=593561.msg4187411#msg4187411 date=1356364506]

Who cares, I used it so I wasn’t blatantly releasing the source.

I have to spend 5 extra seconds running a program to remove ZKM’s transforms until I get the source, wow! Excluding the naming. That feature is actually useful.

Anyone with sense cares about performance. Intel Atoms are a thing and the rendering is being done by the CPU. I like to multi-task when playing incredibly boring private servers.[/quote]PIIs are a thing, but people don’t make games to run on shit hardware anymore.

“I have good hardware, so you should make the game run like shit in exchange for love all.”[/quote]The way people remove fog is going to cause more stress on the CPU than ZKMs control flow obfuscation. And pretty much every server allows you to remove the fog of war, and I didn’t see you complaining about them…

Furthermore, let’s see some benchmarks that show the alleged huge decrease in performance caused purely by ZKM.

The people setting the fog to 999999 or whatever are idiots.

And sure.

$ java Test
Time taken: 3036 ms.
$ java a
Time taken: 3342 ms.

No exception obfuscation. I don’t have the latest version. Code is this, because it was the first thing that came to mind. Output generated with javap.

10% is a very significant difference. Especially for such simple code.
[/quote]That is not a reliable or proper benchmark; go look up how to properly benchmark things in Java. Furthermore, you’re looking at a huge number of iterations run without any sleeping. The client has a sleep built into its main loop, which is much larger than the actual time to complete the loop, so the nanosecond differences per iteration aren’t noticeable, especially when the accuracy of the sleep is like 1ms at best.

lol
[/quote]Exactly, you know I’m right, so you’re just trying to play it off as if it’s funny. Anyone that isn’t a complete imbicile knows that is a terrible benchmark and that the accuracy of the sleep method is within 1ms at best (which is using the 2.6 Linux kernel).

Nah, it is funny. Saying that it’s not a “proper benchmark” is typical of you. I really don’t give a shit if it’s a proper benchmark. If it takes 300ms longer to do what it needs to do every time (which it does) then that matters. I think it would literally kill you to admit that’s bad, so I won’t bother continuing this positively delightful conversation.[/quote]It is not a proper benchmark, it’s not even close. You’re measuring things that take nanoseconds to complete using millisecond resolution. You should, at the very least, be using the nanoTime method. Also, you’re not giving it a warm-up, which will optimize most of the terrible performance away. In addition, you’re not testing them under the same conditions, because you’re not running the tests at the same time. I can go on, but those are the three major, and obvious issues with this shitty benchmark.

Also, it’s 306ms for 8 million iterations. The obfuscation adds an additional 38.25 nanoseconds to each iteration. In the RSC client the accuracy of the sleep is only within 1ms, at best, and typically in the range of 10 ms. There is absolutely no way in hell you’ll notice any difference. Shit, a completely untouched client can have swings of more than 4 fps, which is going to be much more than any obfuscation from ZKM, especially once it has ben jit’d.

I think it would literally kill you to admit that’s bad, so I won’t bother continuing this positively delightful conversation.

@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=".S. v2, post:13, topic:475447"][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=593561.msg4187412#msg4187412 date=1356364911]

[quote author=.S. v2 link=topic=593561.msg4187411#msg4187411 date=1356364506]

[quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=593561.msg4187160#msg4187160 date=1356316329]

Who cares, I used it so I wasn’t blatantly releasing the source.

I have to spend 5 extra seconds running a program to remove ZKM’s transforms until I get the source, wow! Excluding the naming. That feature is actually useful.

Anyone with sense cares about performance. Intel Atoms are a thing and the rendering is being done by the CPU. I like to multi-task when playing incredibly boring private servers.[/quote]PIIs are a thing, but people don’t make games to run on shit hardware anymore.

“I have good hardware, so you should make the game run like shit in exchange for love all.”[/quote]The way people remove fog is going to cause more stress on the CPU than ZKMs control flow obfuscation. And pretty much every server allows you to remove the fog of war, and I didn’t see you complaining about them…

Furthermore, let’s see some benchmarks that show the alleged huge decrease in performance caused purely by ZKM.

The people setting the fog to 999999 or whatever are idiots.

And sure.

item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=".S. v2, post:11, topic:475447"][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=593561.msg4187160#msg4187160 date=1356316329]

[quote author=.S. v2 link=topic=593561.msg4187036#msg4187036 date=1356298490]

Who cares, I used it so I wasn’t blatantly releasing the source.

I have to spend 5 extra seconds running a program to remove ZKM’s transforms until I get the source, wow! Excluding the naming. That feature is actually useful.

Anyone with sense cares about performance. Intel Atoms are a thing and the rendering is being done by the CPU. I like to multi-task when playing incredibly boring private servers.[/quote]PIIs are a thing, but people don’t make games to run on shit hardware anymore.

“I have good hardware, so you should make the game run like shit in exchange for love all.”[/quote]The way people remove fog is going to cause more stress on the CPU than ZKMs control flow obfuscation. And pretty much every server allows you to remove the fog of war, and I didn’t see you complaining about them…

Furthermore, let’s see some benchmarks that show the alleged huge decrease in performance caused purely by ZKM.

The people setting the fog to 999999 or whatever are idiots.

And sure.

item.source: How do i release the client? :o

item.title: How do i release the client? :o
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=".S. v2, post:9, topic:475447"][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=593561.msg4187020#msg4187020 date=1356296473]

Who cares, I used it so I wasn’t blatantly releasing the source.

I have to spend 5 extra seconds running a program to remove ZKM’s transforms until I get the source, wow! Excluding the naming. That feature is actually useful.

Anyone with sense cares about performance. Intel Atoms are a thing and the rendering is being done by the CPU. I like to multi-task when playing incredibly boring private servers.[/quote]PIIs are a thing, but people don’t make games to run on shit hardware anymore.

“I have good hardware, so you should make the game run like shit in exchange for love all.”[/quote]The way people remove fog is going to cause more stress on the CPU than ZKMs control flow obfuscation. And pretty much every server allows you to remove the fog of war, and I didn’t see you complaining about them…

Furthermore, let’s see some benchmarks that show the alleged huge decrease in performance caused purely by ZKM.

Read full topic

item.title: How do i release the client? :o
item.dc:creator: @S_v2 .S. v2
item.description:
@S_v2 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:4, topic:475447”][quote author=.S. v2 link=topic=593561.msg4186874#msg4186874 date=1356278777]
be sure to obfuscate it on max settings with an obfuscator with about 10 public deobfuscators and leave a warning to bot developers in every class

(hi projectrsc and hixk respectively)
[/quote]
What? I only used ZKM on prsc, and didn’t add a “warning” like hixk?[/quote]

http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/respectively

Reversible control flow obfuscation (especially in the extremes, i.e. ZKM’s control flow/“exception” obfuscation set to aggressive) is a joke. Using ZKM is completely pointless, you’re just increasing the file size and complicating the bytecode for no reason. It’s been reversed so many times.
